title: Insolvency practices to face scrutiny in post-Hayne inquiry
text:
"There's a range of different professions in this space and we want to come up with recommendations to help small to medium businesses and farmers," she said.

"We want it to be fair for everybody.

"We'll also be asking industry associations, regulators, professionals in the area to come forward with their ideas for how to make the system better."

The probe will initiate discussions with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, the Australian Financial Security Authority and the Treasury Department in coming weeks, as well as with courts, consultants, funders and practitioners in metropolitan and rural and regional areas.

Pressure from Mr Williams, who retired at the May federal election, was crucial to the establishment of the Hayne royal commission. The respected former Nationals senator met with Treasurer Josh Frydenberg during a drought tour last week.

Mr Williams said farmers faced serious difficulties when dealing with insolvency operators.

"We got involved in one case where a receiver was sent in to a farm. The receivers had no idea how to look after the sheep, how to look after the property, how to keep the weeds under control.

"The sheep were neglected. It's a wonder the RSPCA didn't get involved. The place was neglected and hence the property was sold way under market value.

"Often when the administrator, the liquidator, the receiver is put in place, the owners of the business are just booted out and nothing is said."

Praising the banks for some improvement to their practices since the royal commission's final report and her own inquiry into small business loans, Ms Carnell said further change was urgently needed to stop some businesses from going to the wall.

"A lot of the stories we've heard during our banking inquiry, the royal commission and previous parliamentary inquires weren't as rosy," the former ACT chief minister said.

"It's good to see things have improved but there's still some very real issues to be addressed."

The review will present an interim report on December 11.
description: Having escaped scrutiny from the Hayne banking royal commission, insolvency practices and the treatment of small business under external administration are set to be reviewed.
